attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Length of feature in internal units.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Area of feature in internal units squared.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Name of the country or subnational area (administrative division).

Concatenation of all administrative division names separated by underscores ("_"), beginning with the country name and ending with the division name for the lowest subnational administrative order (level). The field serves as one for name sorting and ordering.

Identical subnational area identifiers in the Excel table, geospatial data file, and Unicode text table, enabling linkage (joining) of the table records to the geospatial data file polygons as attributes.
First-order administrative division name (ADM1), i.e., provinces.
Second-order administrative division name (ADM2), i.e., districts.
Administrative level "0" (ADM0/country); administrative level "1" (ADM1); administrative level "2" (ADM2); administrative level "3" (ADM3); administrative level "4" (ADM4).
Any notes about Zambia or its subnational divisions, which may include former names or alternate names or spellings.

dataIdInfo.idAbs: Annual Five-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for 2000 to 2025 for the national, and first- and second-order administrative division levels of Zambia were prepared by the U.S. Census Bureau for joining (linking) to shapefiles as attribute data. The estimates are consistent with the midyear national projections from the U.S. Census Bureau International Data Base (IDB).
dataIdInfo.idPurp: The U.S. Census Bureau is providing annual subnational five-year age group population estimates by sex for Zambia for 2000-2025 in a geographic information system (GIS) for users of the Spatial Data Repository, funded by the U.S. President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR).
dataIdInfo.idCredit:
CENSUS DATA 2010 Age-Sex Data: 2010 Census of Population and Housing Descriptive Tables, Series A - Population Size Tables, Table A3: Population (De Jure) by Single Year Age, Sex and District, Rural/Urban, and Table A7: Population (De jure) by District, 5 Year Age Group, Sex, Constituency, Ward and Rural/Urban. Zambia Central Statistical Office. Available online at http://www.zamstats.gov.zm/index.php/publications/category/14-2010?download=49:2010-census-provincial-descriptive-tables (the downloaded Zip file contains a PDF report for each of Zambia's 10 provinces, accessed August 10, 2021).
2000 Population Total Data: 2000 Census of Population and Housing Summary Report, Annex 3: Households and Population Distribution by Province, District, Constituency, and Ward. Zambia Central Statistical Office. Available online at http://www.zamstats.gov.zm/index.php/publications/category/13-2000?download=15:2000-census-of-population-and-housing-summary-report (accessed August 10, 2021).
The U.S. Census Bureau cannot guarantee the accuracy of non-U.S. census and survey data.
GEOSPATIAL BOUNDARIES International boundaries coincide with the Large Scale International Boundaries (LSIB) dataset from the U.S. Department of State, Office of the Geographer and Global Issues. Available online at http://geonode.state.gov (accessed August 10, 2021). Geospatial data for the second-order administrative divisions of Zambia were downloaded from the United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction, available online at http://riskprofilesundrr.org/layers/geonode:popward#more, "Ward Boundaries of Zambia" (accessed August 10, 2021). The U.S. Census Bureau cannot guarantee the accuracy of boundary placements.
NATIONAL ESTIMATES AND PROJECTIONS U.S. Census Bureau, Population Division. International Data Base, April 2021 release, available online at http://www.census.gov/data-tools/demo/idb/, accessed August 10, 2021.
NATIONAL AND SUBNATIONAL AREA NAMES AND CODES (1) U.S. National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency. NGA GEOnet Names Server (GNS), available at http://geonames.nga.mil/gns/html/ (accessed August 10, 2021). Contains geographic area names from the U.S. Board on Geographic Names and the U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS) codes. (2) U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC) Standard. NSG Standards Registry, available at http://nsgreg.nga.mil/genc/discovery (accessed August 10, 2021).

Consts.useLimit: U.S. Census Bureau population estimates: None. Acknowledgment of the Census Bureau would be appreciated in products derived from its population estimates. The subnational boundaries used for this shapefile were downloaded by the U.S. Census Bureau from a publicly available source for this product. The international boundaries are derived from the Large Scale International Boundaries (LSIB) dataset (public domain).

dataIdInfo.suppInfo:
SUBNATIONAL DIVISIONS Zambia's second-order administrative divisions: 74 districts as of the 2010 census.
SHAPEFILES The original shapefile downloaded from the United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction had 1,416 polygons and matched the 2010 census wards (fourth-order administrative divisions), after a change to the subnational boundaries by USCB staff: (1) A total of five polygons were added by USCB staff to the original shapefile to match 2000 census wards. Polygons were created for Miluji in North-Western Province, Mumba in Central Province, Musonda in Luapula Province, Ipusukilo in Northern Province, and Katiula in Eastern Province.
This change resulted in a shapefile with 1,421 polygons, one for each of Zambia's fourth-order administrative divisions. The U.S. Census Bureau aligned the shapefile's national boundary to the Large Scale International Boundary Line (LSIB) polygon file from the U.S. Department of State, Office of the Geographer and Global Issues. Finally, the LSIB-aligned shapefile was dissolved into 74 polygons, one for each of Zambia's second-order administrative divisions (districts) as reported by the Zambia Central Statistical Office in the 2010 census.
CENSUS DATA INTERPOLATION The 2000 census totals had the following differences in geography that have been modified to their 2010 locations in the estimates presented here, requiring interpolation and adjustment of 2000 population data by USCB staff: (1) The total number of wards in Zambia increased from 1,286 at the time of the 2000 census, to 1,421 by the time of the 2010 census. These new wards were formed from parts of single or multiple existing wards, as noted in the "USCBCMNT" field. (2) To interpolate the subnational boundary changes in Zambia that occurred between 2000 and 2010, shapefiles were used by USCB staff that matched the wards for each census year. According to these shapefiles, there were a number of wards in Zambia that moved locations entirely. For example, in Luapula Province, the area known as Muleshi Ward in 2010 was known as Lwingishi Ward in 2000, and the area known as Lwingishi Ward in 2010 was known as Chibeleka Ward in 2000. In addition, there were many other wards that changed size between census, but whose boundaries generally stayed in the same place. There were too many of these types of boundary changes to list, so the notes in the "USCBCMNT" field refer only to the newly formed wards mentioned above. (3) Chowa and Ipumbu Wards in Copperbelt Province, Chadzombe Ward in Eastern Province, and Munyeke Ward in Southern Province ceased to exist sometime between the 2000 and 2010 censuses.
For new wards that were fully formed from part of a single area, where boundaries and population data were not available for the next administrative level down, the total population of the original area in 2000 was divided proportionally according to the populations of the new areas in 2010. For new wards that were formed from parts of multiple original areas, where boundaries and population data were not available for the next administrative level down, the total population of the new area in 2010 was divided proportionally according to the land areas of the multiple original pieces in square kilometers.
ADDITIONAL NOTES (1) Single-year ages and the open-ended age group 95 years-and-older data for the national, first-, and second-order administrative divisions of Zambia were summed by USCB staff into 5-year age groups with an open-ended age group of 80 years-and-older. (2) Age-sex data for the third- and fourth-order administrative divisions of Zambia were only available with an open-ended age group of 65 years-and-older. Values for the five-year age groups of 65-69, 70-74, 75-79, and 80 years-and-older, all by sex, for the third- and fourth-order administrative divisions were calculated by USCB staff by disaggregating the 65 years-and-older age group proportionally, according to their second-order administrative division totals.
FEATURE AND ATTRIBUTE DETAILS The 2000-2025 population estimates for Zambia's administrative divisions are provided in the following two tables: (1) The Unicode tab-delimited text file (table) "Zambia_5yr_age_sex_2000-2025_uscb_oct2021.txt," which can be joined to the shapefile via the common field "GEOMATCH." (2) The Excel table "Zambia_5yr_age_sex_2000-2025_508_uscb_oct2021.xlsx," formatted for accessibility in compliance with Section 508 of the U.S. Government's Federal Rehabilitation Act.
Details on processing of the census data and calculation of 2000-2025 estimates are provided in the "Census Metadata" tab of the Excel file and "Methods for Calculating 5-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for Subnational Areas" document. For the subnational areas, the U.S. Board on Geographic Names (BGN) "approved" names from the NGA GEOnet Names Server (cited in the "Credits") were used. For any area that a BGN name was not available, the name from the national census was used. Official codes for the subnational areas from the country's national statistical office, when available, are entered in the "NSO_CODE" field in both the text and Excel tables. Information on any alternative area names or recent name or boundary changes is entered in the "USCBCMNT" field. A partial list of the fields in the Excel and Unicode text files, including all fields identifying geographic names and codes, is provided in the Excel file's "Data Dictionary" tab. More detail on the U.S. Census Bureau subnational age and sex group estimates and maps for PEPFAR can be found in the document "Subnational Population Estimates Components for the Spatial Data Repository." It includes a data dictionary that is similar to that in the Excel table.
METHODOLOGY For more information, see the following methodology documents in the Spatial Data Repository: (1) "U.S. Census Bureau Methodology for SDR Subnational Population Estimates." (2) "U.S. Census Bureau Methods for Calculating 5-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for Subnational Areas." (3) "Instructions for Joining Subnational Population Data to Shapefiles."
ACCESS The U.S. Census Bureau’s products for PEPFAR can be accessed from the Spatial Data Repository at http://spatialdata.dhsprogram.com/home/, which also provides access to data and maps from the DHS (Demographic and Health Surveys) Program. A zipped file containing shapefiles with metadata, an Excel workbook with subnational population estimates, and a Unicode tab-delimited text file is available for each country. PEPFAR products are also available on the Census Bureau website at http://www.census.gov/geographies/mapping-files/time-series/demo/international-programs/subnationalpopulation.html for download.
